Article.Abstract: Experimental models of Chagas' disease, an infection caused by the intracellular protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, have demonstrated the crucial immunoprotective role played by CD8(+) T lymphocytes. These cells dominate inflammatory foci in parasitized tissues and their elimination from mice leads to uncontrolled parasite replication and subsequent death of the infected host. A trypomastigote surface antigen, TSA-1, and two amastigote surface molecules, ASP-1 and ASP-2, were recently identified as targets of CD8(+) cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTL) in T. cruzi-infected mice. Until now, however, there was no evidence for the development of parasite-specific CTL in T. cruzi-infected humans. In this study, human CTL specific for TSA-1-, ASP-1-, and ASP-2-derived peptides were detected in the peripheral blood mononuclear cells from 21 of 24 HLA-A2(+) T. cruzi-infected patients. CTL recognition was antigen specific, A2-restricted, and CD8(+) T cell-dependent. Demonstration of human CTL against T. cruzi and against target molecules identified using the murine model provides important information for the optimal design and evaluation of vaccines to prevent or ameliorate Chagas' disease.
Article.ArticleTitle: Human infection with Trypanosoma cruzi induces parasite antigen-specific cytotoxic T lymphocyte responses.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Cellular Biology, University of Georgia, Athens, Georgia 30602, USA.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Antigens, Protozoan;Antigens, Surface;Epitopes;HLA-A2 Antigen;Membrane Proteins;Peptide Fragments;Variant Surface Glycoproteins, Trypanosoma;trypomastigote specific surface antigen;amastigote surface protein-1;Neuraminidase
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Animals; Antigens, Protozoan(immunology); Antigens, Surface(immunology); CD8-Positive T-Lymphocytes(immunology); Cell Line; Chagas Disease(immunology; parasitology); Disease Models, Animal; Epitopes(immunology); HLA-A2 Antigen(immunology); Humans; Immunization; Membrane Proteins(immunology); Neuraminidase(immunology; metabolism); Peptide Fragments(immunology); Protein Binding(immunology); T-Lymphocytes, Cytotoxic(immunology); Trypanosoma cruzi(immunology); Variant Surface Glycoproteins, Trypanosoma

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 1 dose of 1,000 followed by 0.2 million trypomastigotes

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were infected with T. cruzi blood form trypomastigotes and were challenged subcutaneously three months later with tissue culture-derived trypomastigotes. Splenocytes were isolated and stimulated in vitro with epitope-coated syngeneic irradiated LPS blasts.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 1 dose of 50 μg

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized at base of tail. Eleven days post infection, splenocytes were isolated and stimulated in vitro with epitope-coated syngeneic irradiated LPS blasts.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Exposure with existing immune reactivity without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were isolated from seropositive donors living in Chagas's endemic region. Based on the serological and exposure patterns, these donors are classified as being in the indeterminate asymptomatic chronic phase of Chagasâ€™ disease. Authors state they are infected, although no conclusive evidence for this fact is provided in the manuscript. Cells were re-stimulated with the epitope prior to assay.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Exposure with existing immune reactivity without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were isolated from seropositive donors living in Chagas's endemic region. Based on the serological and exposure patterns, these donors are classified as being in the indeterminate asymptomatic chronic phase of Chagasâ€™ disease. Authors state they are infected, although no conclusive evidence for this fact is provided in the manuscript. Cells were re-stimulated with the epitope prior to assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Antigen presenting cells were HLA-A2.1-matched C1R cells that expressed transfected HLA-A2.1 gene. CTL activity was observed with purified CD8 cells, but not with CD4 cells.
